captions.text:
A check-valve is an amazing little device
that lets a liquid or a gas flow one way only.

We'll need some to make a low cost water pump,
but buying them can be a little pricy. So

in this project we'll be making our own, out
of common materials, and for less than
a dollar.

For this project, I'm using a 3/4" male PVC
slip adaptor, 3/4" tubing, a 3/4" plastic

ball, and an O-ring. I chose this adaptor
because there's a little ledge on the inside

where the O-ring can sit. And it should look
like this. The ball needs to be large enough

that it won't push through the throat, but
small enough that it doesn't touch the sides.

Attaching the tube at this point won't really
do any good because the ball will roll right

out. We need a way to secure it in position,
so let's make a mark on our tube 5/8" from

the bottom and use a 1/16" bit to drill a
small hole in the tube, continuing right on

through the other side. Now you'll need a
strong piece of metal, like a nail or a thick

paperclip. I'm using one of these brad nails
that go to my nail gun. Whatever you use,

it needs to be strong, and long enough to
push all the way through the tube. The ends

of the nail will need to be flush with the
sides of the pipe, so we can go ahead and

clip the end with the nail head on it, and
now we've got ourselves a retaining bar that's

perfectly flush on both sides. The next step
is to prime our connections and place the

O-ring into place inside the adaptor. Now
let's drop in the ball and double check that

everything is seated properly. PVC cement
is added to the pipe, making sure it covers

the holes where the nail is set. Then the
pipe is pushed down to the point where the

holes dip just below the rim of the adaptor
so that when the glue sets, this connection

will be completely air-tight. You can build
this valve into any length of PVC pipe you

want, but I'm using this 1-1/2" piece because
it's just long enough to accept another adaptor.

When it's glued and pushed together, it makes
a nice little compact unit, with only a slight
gap separating the two ends. I took

the opportunity to make 4 of these valves
and a visual inspection on the inside shows

that the ball and O-ring are still seated
properly in place, and the retention bar keeps

it all together. To finish up, I gave these
a quick paint job, and wrapped one end with

a bit of electrical tape to indicate the direction
of flow, similar to the marking you'd find

on an electrical diode. A fluid can pass freely
in one direction, but if the valve is turned

around, the pressure closes the valve and
the fluid is blocked. The quality of the seal

can be tested by dipping the pressurized valve
in a bowl of water. This will show us if any

air is escaping at all. The pressure can be
released though, by pushing up on the inside

of the valve to break the seal between the
ball and the O-ring. I tried using a couple

of these valves to make a hand pump, which
you'll be able to find in another project.

It'll compress air, and move water at over
5 gallons per minute. You can even create

enough suction to form a makeshift vacuum
pump. The threaded ends of the valves make

them easy to connect, replace or rearrange
whenever needed. Just for curiosity, let's

pressure-test the valve by hooking it up to
an air compressor using this pneumatic adaptor

that we made in the Rocket Rifle project.
The system's set at 20PSI, and you can see

the valve close off and prevent any air from
leaking. When I crank it up to 50PSI, the
pressure difference is a little more obvious by the compression of the O-ring, and I'm really impressed at

how well it works. As an alternative, I found
that a rubber bouncy ball could replace the

entire valve mechanism for low pressure applications.
Since the ball is rubber, you don't need an

O-ring to seal the port. To make it work,
just grab a sharp knife and a cutting board,

and begin cutting the top third of the ball
very slowly, until you've sliced right through

it. Now re-insert the ball with the round
side facing down, and simply slide the tube

in overtop. Amazingly it's that easy, and
my kids use it for blowing up balloons. Well

there's how to make some useful pressure rated
check-valves for as little as 35¢. If you

like this project, perhaps you'll like some
of my others. Check them out at www.thekingofrandom.com

title: How To Make a One-Way Check Valve - For Cheap!!

comments.author: skydyverjym

comments.text:
+skydyverjym I know exactly what he is talking about genius. Right around 
0:40 you can see straight into the slip adapter which is where the o-ring 
is seated. You can also see it at 1:28. It's *not* a groove. It's a 
step *exactly* as I described. That's the step which is the thickness of 
the wall of the pvc pipe which fits in there. That step is what allows the 
inner diameter of the slip adapter to that of the pipe itself so there is 
no loss or change in pressure.

If, insted of finding a flat step you instead are finding a sloped area 
like in this picture: http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/318mWHLfIRL.jpg

then you are likely using a reducer and not an adapter. The reducer has 
sloped walls in order to convert the 3/4 in pipe to a smaller inner 
diameter as in the example I provided which goes from 3/4 to 1/2 inch.

If that's the case then you could easily alter the plan to make use of a 
simple 3/4 inch pvc clip coupling:

http://www.irrigationsupplydepot.com/34pvcslipcoupling.aspx#.VURG2flVhBc

Basically you would have the slip adapter attaching to a short piece of 
pipe, about an inch and a half to accommodate the depth of both fittings. 
On the other side of the pipe you attach the slip coupling linked right 
above. On the other side of the step in that coupling you place the o-ring 
then the marble then the piece of pvc pipe with the retention bar then the 
other threaded slip adapter.

Also, I found this bit rather amusing "*i am not talking about the slip, i 
am talking about the groove he points out in detail and explains about 
where the o-ring sits. it is at the butt of the slip.*"

Soooo.....are you talking about the slip or not?

Lol.

And by the way, I know what I'm talking about genius. I've laid out 
numerous lawn irrigation systems and have done tons of plumbing jobs in my 
life.

Best of luck chump.
comments.author: KamekoBruns

comments.text:
oh my fucking god. watch the damn video again. i am not talking about the 
slip, i am talking about the groove he points out in detail and explains 
about where the o-ring sits. it is at the butt of the slip. WATCH THE VIDEO 
CLOSELY. regular slip adapters don't work as well, i have tried them, quite 
a few of them.
comments.author: skydyverjym

comments.text:
How can there be no step inside the slip adapter? That's where the 
non-threaded pip will rest. Without a step the pipe would just slide right 
through the thread adapter. The inner diameter of the threaded section 
matched the inner diameter of the non-threaded pipe while the slip section 
of the adapter fits the other diameter of the non-threaded pipe. When you 
slide the adapter over the non-threaded pipe the end of the pipe buts up 
against the step inside the adapter so the inner diameter is consistent. 
All the o-ring does is get squeezed in between that step and the end of the 
non-threaded pipe.

Maybe you picked up something else but I picked up mine from Home Depot 
easy peasy.
comments.author: KamekoBruns

comments.text:
watch that video again real close.  that slip adapter has a groove down 
inside it.  he explains it and shows it in detail.  I have made these with 
regular slip adapters with no groove and they don't work as well especially 
pneumatic.  haven't tested hydraulic yet.  I just got out of the hospital. 
 but the one he uses has a groove and there is a reason for it's necessity.

comments.author: skydyverjym

comments.text:
+skydyverjym What he said in the beginning was they they would be making 
them for less than a dollar. He is making a bunch of them so if you can 
source enough material at the right price that's certainly possible. The 
3/4 inch balls I linked two are sold in packs of 10@ $0.81 a dollar which 
makes the final cost on those $8.10. Even if the price per check valve came 
out to $2 a piece I think that's still rather cheap.

In fact, I just did some pricing and it look like you can pull these 
together for just under $2 a piece which is quite cheap.10 acrylic balls @ 
$8.10
20 3/4" male PVC slip adapters @ $5.20
10 3/4" rubber o-rings @ $4.90
24 inches of 3/4" sch 40 PVC pipe @ 1.42


Altogether that's $19.62 in my area and since we are making 10 of them 
that's an individual cost of just under $2.


I think that meets the "for cheap" definition.

comments.author: any12u

comments.text:
ok. going to answer all the questions the VC won't or can't.  the 3/4" 
fittings with that little groove aren't available anywhere near where i am, 
i could probably find an o-ring in an assortment that may fit inside the 
regular 3/4 fittings but any ball i have found just falls right through. 
 the solution is that almost ANY 3/4" fitting like the one he uses, even 
without the little o-ring groove can work with hilman rubber grommet 
instead AND then it will make finding the specific size acrylic ball 100% 
completely MOOT. a hilman 7.1 mm, 9/32T rubber grommet with a 31/32" inside 
diameter and 1/2" outside diameter will fit exactly inside the fitting 
where the o-ring goes perfectly making the possibility of using almost ANY 
little ball you can find.  At walmart they have different bags of 
decorative marbles in the arts and crafts, a bag of slingshot ammo in the 
camping section, marbles in the toy section, even the smallest one i can 
find, the one inside a paint can will work with a hillman grommet, UPC # 
0-08236-71652-8, hillman H#991261, from lowes in the little screws and 
bolts and assorted hard to find items.

i don't make videos and if i did, i couldn't edit them and you would all 
hate me for it. but if i could i would upload a video response to this one. 
 perhaps someone out there who can, will.

comments.author: Ben Dover

comments.text:
I don't trust this unit for HHO. Maybe for balloons but I need a check 
valve that properly stops flash backs. I had 3 check valves on 1 unit and 
it seems after a dozen or so flashbacks, the check valves stop working. I 
had 3 valves on 1 hose that all failed from 1 flashback, blew into the 
bubbler and fortunately I had the hose on loose so the hose blew off rather 
than the bubbler head. I think the problem is the gas explodes so fast, 
that the flame passes through the valves before the actual air pressure can 
close them. So I need to build some super heavy duty 100% fail proof check 
valve. And I'm definitely not relying on this unit.﻿
comments.author: Robert Cece

comments.author: plastiekske

comments.text:
+Erik Ware Thanks & I already did that. I packed my torch with medium 
bronze wool and literally slammed it in with a hammer. I'd slam it once, 
see if I could breathe through, slam again, do a breathe test. I basically 
kept slamming till it took a bit of pressure to blow through the torch 
head. 

However, with further testing I've found out that the way I shut off the 
torch seems to be the main problem.

When I shut the torch off, I slowly turn the knob off. And that seems to 
have been the issue. Now I engraved a mark on the knob with my dremel. So I 
slowly close the knob on the torch, but I know after that "dash" I need to 
QUICKLY shut the valve. As in, I jerk my wrist as quickly as possible and 
now it seems like flashbacks have stopped completely.

The only thing I don't like is you really need to be QUICK with the valve. 
If I'm just a teeny bit slow I'll get a flashback. I'm new to this whole 
HHO thing and still can't get over how fast this gas burns. It's not even 
like a "burn". It almost seems like the gas "detonates" if that makes sense.
comments.author: Robert Cece

comments.text:
How about building or buying a flame arrestor and installing it as close as 
possible to where the flashbacks occur.

comments.text:
I'm translating a check valve installation instructions and it says to, in 
the case of direction changing "take away the check valve so that it is 
outside the turbulence area" with the following brackets right after that 
(between 3 and 5 times the ND before and after).
I can't for the life of me figure out what the text in brackets means and 
what the hell the ND stands for. If anyone could shed light on this in the 
next 5 hours, I'd be extremely grateful.
*Asking on youtube as a desperation act after an hour of googling*﻿
comments.author: xxDrain

comments.text: +ib9rt Alright than, thanks for clarifying.
comments.author: xxDrain

comments.text:
Sure it's a bit late now, but what the strange text was trying to say is 
that when check valves are installed in piping runs they should be 
installed with a minimum length of straight pipe before and after. A rule 
of thumb for the minimum length is 3-5 times the nominal pipe diameter. The 
reason for this is to avoid turbulence from bends or other fittings 
interfering with the operation of the check valve.
comments.author: ib9rt

comments.text: +skydyverjym No worries. It can't be a sore subject if it's over and done :P
comments.author: xxDrain

comments.text:
you're right and sorry to have brought up a sore subject.

it's sad that everybody writes for an audience of PhD engineers and ignores 
the layman.
comments.author: skydyverjym

comments.text:
+skydyverjym I don't even care anymore, but now that I look at it again the 
only way it could make sense is to mean that the valve must be placed far 
enough from the origin of any turbulence to not be affected by it, and 
there should be between 3 to 5 times the nominal distance (to any 
turbulence) on either side of the valve.
But shit, the wording still doesn't make it clear. It could be my lack of 
expertise in the given field, but it could just as easily simply be shitty 
writing or an error... go figure.
#translationproblems

comments.text:
How about a check valve that will handle hot water. Use: off - grid hot 
water heater using a copper coil on a stove pipe. The check valve would be 
at the low end of the coil to stop blow back when the water expands in the 
coil to allow for that pressure to push the water into the catch. In this 
example I'm thinking of an old hot water heater with both inlet and out 
circulating thru the heater coil.﻿

comments.author: Noah McIntire

comments.text: Genius! Subscribed.﻿
comments.author: BrainToMush

comments.text: This is so cool :)  thanks for making these﻿
comments.author: JFQlikesengineering

comments.text:
Why did you need to cut the squishy ball? It seems to me it would work 
better if you used it whole. It would be less likely to deform and get 
stuck in the valve, and it also wouldn't turn so that air could flow past 
the flat side. Fluid actually flows better around a round ball, doesn't it?

You must have gotten a very good deal on those PVC adapters because they 
normally go for about the same as you're quoting for the whole project. Did 
you find a 2 for 1 sale somewhere? And of course you also have to have some 
acrylic balls of exactly the right size in your spare parts bin, and a hunk 
PVC pipe you can cut a couple of inches off of. You'll also have to have 
some leftover PVC glue and primer. A more realistic price would be $3.50 
than $.35.﻿
comments.author: dlwatib

comments.text:
Think of the flat side as a sail. The bigger the surface the more area to 
push against, as in the bigger the sail the faster the boat goes.The point 
is you don't want to let the pressure side flow backward.

comments.text:
I think maybe the pipe inserted into the threaded fitting sits close to the 
flat spot of the ball which in turn takes the place of the pin nail and 
also doesnt let the ball rotate... but if the flat spot sat too nicely 
against the pipe it would be sealing off flow that direction as well so I 
may just be talking out my ...
